= |website = |footnotes = }} '''Tobelo''' is a town and also a district on the eastern [[Indonesia]]n island of [[Halmahera]]. It is the capital of the regency (''kabupaten'') of [[North Halmahera]], part of the province of [[North Maluku]].<ref>Hedman, p. 278</ref> The city was formalised as the capital of North Halmahera in the district elections held in 2004. It has a population of approximately 33,700.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://portal.malutpost.co.id/en/daerah/halut/item/7323-penduduk-halut-190955-jiwa|title=Penduduk Halut 190.955 Jiwa|website=portal.malutpost.co.id|access-date=2016-05-03|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160509133441/http://portal.malutpost.co.id/en/daerah/halut/item/7323-penduduk-halut-190955-jiwa|archivedate=2016-05-09|df=}}</ref> A palm tree lined coastal road connects Tobelo to [[Galela]]. The town is predominantly [[Christian]] and a [[Protestant Church]] has existed in Tobelo since at least 1924.
==Religion== [[Muslims]] and Christians had lived amicably in this town of North Halmahera from the 16th century. However, [[North Maluku]] province has a Muslim majority. The coastal road from [[Galela]] to Tobelo passes through neighboring Muslim and Christian villages. Living peacefully, these two communities followed the local cultural tradition of the ''Hibua Lamo'' (a pact between Muslims and Christians to live together without aggressive designs on each other and cooperating on all matters of mutual interest).<ref name="Wilson">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YdLRVGlmvbcC&pg=PA96&dq=Tobelo+North+Maluku&hl=en&ei=I_8ZTL7MFM6Ocauw8foJ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCQQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Tobelo%20North%20Maluku&f=false|title=Ethno-religious violence in Indonesia: from soil to God|last=Wilson|first=Chris|publisher=Routledge|year=2008|isbn=0-415-45380-1|pages=96–99|accessdate=2010-06-17}}</ref>
===Communal Violence=== Violence broke out in Tobelo in December 1999. According to Duncan (2001), the roots of the conflict "focused on plans by the regional government to create a new district (kecamatan) of Makian Daratan from the southern half of the Kao District." <ref>Duncan, Christopher. 2001. The aftermath of civil war. Inside Indonesia 69. Online: http://www.insideindonesia.org/edition-69-jan-mar-2002/the-aftermath-of-civil-war-3007422</ref> Initial reconciliation efforts at the district level worked for some time in preventing any clashes and assuage hurt feelings. The religious violence, which simmered in January 1999 in Ambon culminated in rioting in Tobelo by end of December 1999. This rioting was further triggered by the fleeing of several thousand Christians{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} from [[Central Halmahera]], and Tobelo had turned into a [[refugee camp]]. Though the rioting has been quelled, the mistrust between the two communities prevails.<ref name=Wilson/> Galela District with its own language is another place where remnants of strife (burnt out churches and mosques) between the religious groups are still seen with military checkposts established to prevent any further disturbances in the region.<ref name="Witton">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dmDYLxcPDPoC&pg=PA830&dq=Tobelo+North+Maluku&hl=en&ei=I_8ZTL7MFM6Ocauw8foJ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CDsQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=Tobelo%20North%20Maluku&f=false|title=Indonesia|last=Witton|first=Patrick|publisher=Lonely Planet|year=2003|isbn=1-74059-154-2|pages=830–831|author2=Mark Elliott}}</ref> In the ultimate analysis, it is reported that the sectarian violence in 1999–2000 had resulted in 2000 Muslim deaths in Maluku and a population displacement of 200,000 Muslim people in the region. Tobelo was the worst affected as over 100,000 Muslim people were from Tobelo and villages to its south, who fled to the island of [[Ternate]] and [[Morotai]] during early 2000. Nearly 70% of them returned subsequently as the situation was controlled.{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}}<ref name= Hedman>{{Cite book|last= Hedman |first= Eva-Lotta E.|title= Conflict, violence, and displacement in Indonesia|work=Old Spirits and new names|page=281|accessdate=2010-06-18|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EUDii8kvQYAC&pg=PA278&lpg=PA278&dq=History+of+Tobelo+town+in+Indonesia&source=bl&ots=YCuHEILexq&sig=9BkCCxeZolNMFT7_WGvKwSmA_GM&hl=en&ei=BzIbTLvzD8q3rAeGtvmXDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CBgQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=History%20of%20Tobelo%20town%20in%20Indonesia&f=false|publisher= SEAP Publications|year= 2008|isbn=0-87727-745-1}}</ref> However, as a result of violence in 1999–2000, the area is clearly demarcated into Muslim and Christian villages. Tobelo is now almost entirely Christian; while Muslims have fled to nearby villages. Remnants of devastation are still evident. There is a discerned process of peace building emerging between the two communities now.<ref name=Harper>{{Cite web|url=http://www.asiainstitute.unimelb.edu.au/programs/indonesian/indonews07_02.pdf|format=pdf|title=Theyears of Travelling Adventurously|pages =3–4|author=Brioni harper|accessdate=2010-06-18|publisher= Asian Institute|date=May–June 2007}}</ref>
==Culture== [[File:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM Halmahera Pakata Tobelo (voorgrond) en rorehe TMnr 10010571.jpg|thumb|left|A vessel on the shore of Tobelo]] Inhabitants of Tobelo are non-Austronesian–speaking people.<ref name=Coppet>{{Cite book|last=Coppet|first= Daniel de|title= Understanding rituals|pages=74–76|accessdate=2010-06-18|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZawOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA74&lpg=PA74&dq=Flora+in++Tobelo+Island&source=bl&ots=LTd028ZZRm&sig=PqbKxTLxYwuHM94wrzShoIXbCNE&hl=en&ei=qKIbTM-KIYqzrAfJqqmtDA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CBQQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q&f=false|publisher= Routledge|year=1992|isbn= 0-415-06121-0}}</ref> Tobelo's predominant Christian character is expressed colourfully at [[Christmas]] with bamboo poles arching over the side of the roads hung with lights and multi-coloured flags. At Easter, local church congregations hold a competition to see who can create the best Easter garden.
One festival of note is the annual North Halmahera Cultural Festival, when the Tobelorese wear full traditional ceremonial dress.<ref name="EII">{{cite web|url=http://www.east-indonesia.info/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=102&Itemid=181|title=Tobelo: Around the Largest Town in Halmahera|publisher=East Indonesian Info|accessdate=June 17, 2010}}</ref>
Traditional Tobelorese weddings are also said to be among the most colourful and the Christians follow traditions during their wedding ceremonies, with traditional music and dance.<ref name="EII"/> A wedding is typically accompanied by traditional Tobelorese music, played with gongs and drums and a [[Cakalele]] dance is usually performed in front of the bride as she approaches the groom.<ref name="EII"/> Around the time of [[New Year]], Tobelo attracts a number of [[Yangere]] groups from all over North Halmahera and perform music and dances.<ref name="EII"/>
The main language of Tobelo, the [[Tobelo language]], is spoken across parts of [[North Halmahera Regency|North Halmahera]] and [[Central Halmahera Regency|Central Halmahera]], by approximately 28,000 people as at 2000.<ref>https://www.ethnologue.com/language/tlb</ref>
===Rituals=== Each year, in April, after the harvest season there is a practice of offering of plates of rice and certain items of basketry by the married women to the Church, duly observing conventional social norms. The offerings are then sold or auctioned during the Sunday services in the premises of the church. The returns from such sales go to the Church funds (''kas gereja''), which are used by the church for providing public services. It is more of ritual than an economic transaction.<ref name=Coppet/>
The other ritual observed in Tobelo is on the first Sunday of January when prayers are offered in the Church for the dead. On this occasion, each family decorates the graves of its deceased with flowers. This is also an occasion when women dressed in military uniform hold a parade through the village and enter houses demanding food and sweets.<ref name=Coppet/>
The rituals observed conform to both pre-Christian Tobelo customs and the post-Christian era culture conforming to the [[Gregorian calendar]]. However, marriages are conducted under the Tobelo customs, rituals and practices. The family units are [[patriarchal|patrilineal]].<ref name=Coppet/>
==Economy== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Tobleomarahai.jpg|thumb|right|The Tobelo sign]] --> Tobelo boasts large swathes of locally owned coconut plantations, supplying hundreds of tonnes of copra (dried coconut flesh) every month to the ports of [[Bitung]] (North Sulawesi) and [[Surabaya]] (East [[Java]]). The city, as the main centre for the North Halmahera has thus become the export hub for copra and other commodities.
[[Pulau Tulang]] is the nearest islet to the town, within swimming distance of the harbour. The Kupa-Kupa beach is located about {{convert|10|km|mi}} from the town, near the oil terminal for the [[Pertamina]] company. The beach is very clean and attracts tourists for snorkelling.<ref name="EII"/> Off the coast of Tobelo town is a group of small, coconut palm covered islands with golden sandy beaches. Longboats frequently travel from them to Tobelo town.<ref name="EII"/> Tobelo contains a hospital and a post office and is an important base and port on the island.<ref name="Handbook">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JUlvd1a14VEC&pg=PA909&dq=tobelo&hl=en&ei=Bf0ZTPrNA5ehsQaikfHOBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CFAQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=tobelo&f=false|title=Footprint Indonesia Handbook|publisher=Footprint Travel Guides|year=2001|isbn=1-900949-51-2|page=909|author=Eliot, J., Capaldi, L., Bickersteth, J.}}</ref>
===Post riots economic recovery=== In the three provinces of North Maluku, Maluku, and Central Sulawesi, following the sectarian conflict in 1999 which centred on Tobelo, devastated the well-being and economy of the people. This needed urgent attention of the authorities concerned in the government through a development process. It was a challenging task to both national and regional governments. The UN Common County Assessment (UNCCA) and [[United Nations Development Assistance Framework (UNDAF)|Development Assistance Framework (UNDAF)]] for 2002–2005 and UNDP’s Country Cooperation Framework decided to pitch in with assistance. They established a programme of linking relief and longer-term development as part of the UN’s support to Indonesia. The UNDP Crisis Prevention and Recovery Unit (CPRU), then launched three support programmes in North Maluku, Maluku and Central Sulawesi, which covered the Galea -Tobelo –South Tobelo Area. Three programmes were launched for the period 2002–2005 envisaging an investment of US $19 million with the objective of: {{quote|providing effective law enforcement, the rule of law and security; improve good governance in regional governments, local legislative bodies (DPRD), and the justice sector; improve policy formulation through increased participation of the public and ensure its implementation; resolve IDPs situations within a framework of building community resilience and social cohesion; and Develop the local economy and reduce unemployment through cross-community economic enterprises, skills training, start-up capital, and business opportunities.<ref>{{Cite web|url= http://www.undp.or.id/programme/cpr/ptd.asp|title= UNDP Crisis Prevention and Recovery Programme|accessdate=2010-06-18|publisher= United Nations Development Programme, Indonesia}}</ref>}}
UNDP launched development project under the Galea – Tobelo – South Tobelo Area Recovery projects in 2002–2003, involved several projects for rural electrification, health facilities (capacity building), transportation, labour-intensive projects of roads and drainage, social activities of cross community collaboration projects of culture and sports empowerment, construction of bridges, markets, improvement of drainage systems and bus terminals.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.undp.or.id/programme/cpr/documents/project_map_tobelo_february_2003.pdf|format=pdf|title= Galeal Tobelo –South Tobelo Area Recovery projects|year=2003|accessdate=2010-06-18|publisher=UNDP}}</ref> Economy is picking up and there are clear signs of recovery.<ref name=Harper/> However, education facilities are still at the basic level. Tobelo and its neighbourhood are still considered a danger zone for foreigners.<ref name=Harper/>
==Attractions== Tobelo town has many attractions on the islands in its vicinity. One such island is the [[Tagalaya]] where sea is calm and the water is clear. The beaches are clean and have extensive spread of white sand. The major attraction here is the broad spread of [[coral reefs]], which are rich in [[marine life]] at a depth of {{convert|2|-|10|m|ft}}. The locale is also good for swimming and diving.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.halmaherautara.com/en/wisata.php|title=Tourist attractions|accessdate=2010-06-17|publisher=Halmahera Utara Government of North Halmahera Regency}}</ref><ref name=tabelo>{{Cite web|url=http://www.east-indonesia.info/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=102&Itemid=181|title=Tobelo: Around the Largest Town in Halmahera|accessdate=2010-06-17|publisher= Halmahera Utara: Government of North Halmahera Regency}}</ref>
Other attractions in Tabelo neighbourhood are the many beaches, lakes, off-shore islands, forested hills and a volcano. Some of the well-known places are:<ref name=tabelo/>
;Luari beach Luari beach, the ethnic [[Galela]]rese village of [[Luari]] to the north of Tobelo, is on the [[Pacific Ocean]]. It has clear and calm waters and is safe for swimming and [[canoeing]]. [[Snorkelling]] is also done on the [[cape (geography)|cape]] to the north, from where sunset views, over [[Mount Tarakani]] and the coast of Galela, are impressive.<ref name=tabelo/><ref name=Kupaka>{{Cite web|url= http://www.halmaherautara.com/en/wisata.php?hal=2|title=Tourist attractions:Kupaka|accessdate=2010-06-17|publisher=Halmahera Utara Government of North Halmahera Regency}}</ref>
;Kupa Kupa Beach Kupakupa beach, {{convert|10|km|mi}} from the town, has huge [[banyan tree]]s on its shores, which makes the waters in the sheltered location inside the bay ideal for watersports, such as swimming, canoeing and snorkelling. The coral reef at its northern end is stated to be one of the finest. [[Pertamina harbour]] for oil-vessels is also located here.<ref name=tabelo/><ref name=Kupaka/>
;Kumo beach Kumo beach on the Kumo island is the nearest to Tabelo town – a few minutes of motorised canoeing – is the busiest beach in North Halmahera. Its natural surroundings are scenic. Swimming is safe here.<ref name=Kupaka/>
;Tobotobo sea garden Tobotobo Sea Garden in the Toboto village, which is ideal for snorkelling and diving. Thousands of [[bat]]s are seen here clinging to the mangrove trees. White and blue pigeons take bath here.<ref name=Kein>{{cite web|url=http://www.keindonesia.com/2009/01/north-maluku.html|title=North Maluku|accessdate=2010-06-19|publisher=Knowing Exploring Indonesia}}</ref>
; Telaga Paca lake Telaga Paca is a small crater lake close to Tobelo town to the south – a few km off the main road. The lake is set in a backdrop of thickly forested hills. There is also a small village by the same name Talaga Paca near the lake, which has a lookout area erected over stilts in the water to view the lake. A canoe could be hired to paddle in the lake. It is the source of drinking water to the village. Villagers do fishing in the lake.<ref name=tabelo/><ref name=Hibualamo>{{Cite web|url= http://www.halmaherautara.com/en/wisata.php?hal=6 |title=Tourist attractions: Hibualamo|accessdate=2010-06-17|publisher=Halmahera Utara Government of North Halmahera Regency}}</ref>
